title: 103_s1049
content:
The Act titled "Lechuguilla Cave Protection Act of 1993" recognizes the scientific and environmental significance of Lechuguilla Cave and other caves in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. It aims to protect these caves from adverse effects of mineral exploration and development. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS

Cave protection area refers to lands within a specified map area. Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Interior. Other terms have the same meaning as defined in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976.

SEC. 4. LAND WITHDRAWAL. The approximately 6,280 acres of public lands within the cave protection area are withdrawn from all forms of appropriation or disposal under public land laws. The lands are described in a map filed in April 1993. The Secretary will publish a notice with the legal description in the Federal Register. The Secretary will publish a notice in the Federal Register with the legal description of the lands withdrawn under subsection (a) and file the description and map with the relevant committees. The map and legal description will have the same force as if included in the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct errors. Copies of the map and legal description will be available for inspection. The public lands withdrawn under subsection (a) will be managed by the Secretary through the Bureau of Land Management, in accordance with relevant laws including the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. Copies of the map and legal description will be available for public inspection. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT OF EXISTING LEASES. The Secretary will not allow new drilling on valid mineral or geothermal leases within the withdrawn lands to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources of Carlsbad Caverns National Park. Activities on existing leases may be suspended if necessary to prevent adverse impacts. The Secretary prohibits new drilling in Carlsbad Caverns National Park and surrounding cave protection areas until a decision is made in the Dark Canyon Environmental Impact Statement or for 12 months after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary is not required to allow or prohibit new drilling after this period. Negotiations may include agreements for the termination of leases. During the specified period, the Secretary will negotiate agreements with lease holders for the termination of leases or restrictions on activities to protect cave resources. The agreements will consider the value of oil and gas resources. The Secretary will negotiate agreements with lease holders to protect cave resources, considering the value of oil and gas resources. If no agreement is reached, appropriate steps will be taken to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. The Secretary will negotiate agreements with lease holders to protect cave resources, including acquisition of lands if necessary. Cooperation with the State of New Mexico and other parties owning lands within the cave protection area will be sought. The Secretary will seek cooperation from the State of New Mexico and other landowners in the cave protection area to implement restrictions on land use for the protection of Lechuguilla Cave and other resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. SEC. 6. ADDITIONAL PROTECTION AND RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. The Secretary will take additional steps to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park, including limiting access and prohibiting removal of resources for scientific purposes. The Secretary may limit access and prohibit removal of resources from lands owned by the United States for scientific purposes to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. If existing laws are deemed insufficient, the Secretary will seek additional authority from relevant committees. The Secretary may seek additional authority from relevant committees regarding the protection of Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. This Act does not affect the ability to seek compensation under existing laws.
